title: Frozen II
review: A distressingly unnecessary (and fairly tedious) sequel...

title: Frozen II
review: Frozen II is the exact kind of sequel that more film series need: it takes chances (within the framework of a Disney animated feature)...

title: Frozen II
review: [A]n ultimately satisfying story of more mature themes for an audience that's grown out of the dress-up stage.

title: Frozen II
review: should be applauded for taking its own route while maintaining much of what made the original so enjoyable and memorable

title: Frozen II
review: I sincerely appreciated the respect paid toward the Northuldra. The fictional Indigenous tribe based on Sámi culture. A fun and magical film, but way too many songs.

title: Frozen II
review: It makes the world of Frozen feel infinite, even if the characters and the story make it feel like it's a small world after all. Perhaps I should just let it go.

title: Frozen II
review: With no surprises, without looking for its female characters stand out, Frozen 2 disappoints, and misrepresents the magical sense that the first installment had. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Frozen II
review: Will please fans of Anna, Elsa and her friends. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Frozen II
review: The whole movie is esthetically beautiful. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Frozen II
review: Frozen II is a notch below its predecessor but still has a lot to offer.

title: Frozen II
review: The story works well enough and there is enough humor in it to go along with the more serious elements. The animation, by Walt Disney Animation studios, is beautiful.

title: Frozen II
review: Arguably the true stars of Frozen were the Lopez husband-and-wife songwriting team.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: There's a plot in there somewhere, but most of the time it's subsumed by a frenetic attempt to showcase the whole Playmobil range in an extended kinetic eruption of primal sound and primary colour.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: Playmobil: The Movie isn't as funny as some of the direct-to-video Lego-related movies, either, and that's very much the field it competes in, theatrical release or not.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: Best watched running in the background of a playdate for pre-schoolers, buried under the noise of kids' own imaginations but offering the occasional distraction from a total toddler meltdown.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: It does not even work as a commercial, never showing us why these toys could be especially fun to play with.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: But much like the Playmobil toys, with their poky feet and weird, lobster-like hands, Playmobil: The Movie is similar but inferior to the Lego equivalent.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: [F]or a movie so clearly doubling as product placement, it's also fun, a cartoon (bookended by live-action sequences) which allows talented actors to riff on unexpected themes.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: There is a gentleness and simplicity to the adventure-seeking vibe of Playmobil: The Movie that will work particularly well for very young audiences.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: A mess.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: This is a vastly inferior toy-to-film IP expansion, with duller songs, dumber jokes, and forgettable voice work.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: Akin to a cheap toy knockoff of toxic materials, Playmobil wields whimsy that is generic, tiresome, and probably isn't safe for young children.

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: It feels like they put 1000 ideas into a bucket and picked one out each week to create the script

title: Playmobil: The Movie
review: There's very little in "Playmobil" to suggest the film isn't just a convenient tour of the playsets you can find at your local department store toy aisle.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: Shaun's new film is for the whole family to enjoy. [Full review in Spanish]

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: You can see the major twists and emotional beats coming from a mile away, but that's part of Farmageddon's soothing charm, too: You don't have to worry too much when things look dire, because you know it'll all turn out okay in the end.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: A sly, clever, and funny animated film. ... A sheer delight.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: I was delighted throughout.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: The very adorable, very cute A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon is charming top to bottom, with sly sight gags and a rapturously colorful stop-motion animation style.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: Any money Netflix spends making movies with Aardman is welcome, and well spent.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: It's not as inspired as the original, but it's unbelievably sweet.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: A novelty in the contemporary landscapes of children's movies.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: Shaun the Sheep is an antidote to the many babbling SpongeBobs, catchphrase-spewing anthropomorphs and singing analogs for Target-exclusive merchandise that dominate animation.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: Unabashedly whimsical childishness carried off with such intoxicating upbeat energy that it's pure bliss to watch it with or without a child in tow.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: It's a great film to watch as a family and everyone will laugh and enjoy the cuteness together. And of course the claymation animation is so well executed.

title: A Shaun the Sheep Movie: Farmageddon
review: This sequel could do with fewer recycled references to the genre it joins, but the experience is still light and frothy enough that the smile likely won't leave your face as it breezes by.

title: The Night Clerk
review: For an alleged psychological thriller, The Night Clerk has no thrills, suspense or tension.

title: The Night Clerk
review: Forget the half-baked investigation and quarter-baked love story -- the real mystery here is how this movie is so boring.

title: The Night Clerk
review: [I]t's a bit ironic that in hindsight The Night Clerk will be remembered, if at all, as a movie de Armas was way too good for-an unfortunate mile marker on her road to movie stardom.

title: The Night Clerk
review: The film may intend to be a Rear Window for the mini-cam era, but it lacks Hitchockian perplexity and perversity.

title: The Night Clerk
review: Those anticipating something more traditionally calibrated will likely be disappointed with the film's muted thrills and noncommittal denouement, but the elegantly composed film nevertheless makes for a creepy, contemplative entry in the Cristofer canon.

title: The Night Clerk
review: The police procedural aspects of "The Night Clerk" are as second-rate as the detective's investigation. But the movie's more emotional quandaries compel...

title: The Night Clerk
review: Not only that; the film lacks rising tension - there are too many lulls in the action to keep the suspense going.

title: The Night Clerk
review: Tye Sheridan, in an unusual role, plays Bart well as a tech savvy young man with Asperger's syndrome. The young actor obviously studied well and is convincing. But is this film?

title: The Night Clerk
review: It's difficult, if not impossible, to imagine a more tedious, tiresome, more lifeless attempt at a neo-noir thriller.

title: The Night Clerk
review: Not too many discernible thrills.

title: The Night Clerk
review: The Night Clerk brings on the thrills as it unravels in interesting ways. I wish the excitement could have reached a level ten, but it only goes to a seven, which, ironically, is its score.

title: The Night Clerk
review: Yeah, The Night Clerk is awful.

title: Queen & Slim
review: With the knock-out performances, symbolic characterization (a Martin Luther King and Malcolm X-like dynamic), and astute observations, Queen & Slim is worth of the crown.

title: Queen & Slim
review: Although I am grateful for the conversations on Black joy and love that this film has sparked, it flattens the experience of being Black in a time of heightened white supremacy, and in the end leads us nowhere.

title: Queen & Slim
review: A remarkable debut, but it is far from being an icon. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Queen & Slim
review: An engrossing and polished debut film that is always pleasant and vibrant. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Queen & Slim
review: It's surprising that Lena Waithe's writing is the most disappointing aspect of the film. While Kaluuya and Turner-Smith are impressive, their characters - Queen especially - remain hugely underdeveloped.

title: Queen & Slim
review: For all the missteps Waithe's script seems to take, it still contains engaging, well-conceived characters (major and minor) and the narrative foundations upon which Matsoukas has built a beautiful and varied set of visuals.

title: Queen & Slim
review: It is not entirely successful in its attempt to transform impotent rage into uplift, but the journey is not without its moments of visual splendour.

title: Queen & Slim
review: The whole film has this dreamy, heady atmosphere, but despite all the things going on around it and all the things it's about...it is, at its heart, a love story.

title: Queen & Slim
review: Set to one of the best soundtracks in years...it still resonates, though it has first-time director flaws...

title: Queen & Slim
review: It will leave you speechless, there is something so tragically beautiful about the film. Heart-wrenching and also, passionately romantic.

title: Queen & Slim
review: As this hot couple unwittingly become Black Lives Matter icons, the provocative script is increasingly peppered with implausible beats and infuriatingly dim decisions but it's worth riding those out to reach the transcendent moments between.

title: Queen & Slim
review: Kaluuya is great, Turner-Smith even better, and while one shocking incident doesn't quite earn its place, the rest is an angry, powerful and surprisingly sexy delight.

title: Uncut Gems
review: It's a brilliantly exhausting movie that gaffer-tapes us to motormouth New York gem dealer and degenerate gambler Howard Ratner... The thrill and despair of the addict are palpable.

title: Uncut Gems
review: Having looked at it closely, I'd say it's being over-valued. But not by much.

title: Uncut Gems
review: When relief finally comes, it's heartbreaking.

title: Uncut Gems
review: Uncut Gems is a fairytale written by the hand of capitalism, where mystical highs are followed by crushing blows -- and there's always a price to pay.

title: Uncut Gems
review: This is the year's most exciting film. You can take that to the bank.

title: Uncut Gems
review: There is more to the Safdies' secret sauce than panic. At first glance the cast has the feel of a group of strangers grabbed at random from the sidewalk, yet it clicks and keeps clicking.

title: Uncut Gems
review: The thing that elevates it above all else is the frenetic energy that infuses every scene, yet calibrated so perfectly so that it stays, barely, on the right side of frustrating. There's nothing more thrilling than that.

title: Uncut Gems
review: Uncut Gems isn't exactly an enjoyable experience - it's stressful and hectic and anxiety-provoking. But, that doesn't take away from the fact that the Safdies have created a drama that is downright fascinating.

title: Uncut Gems
review: Sandler is Oscar-worthy in raw 'Uncut Gems.'

title: Uncut Gems
review: The Safdies have not conferred mystical powers onto their film, but like the black opal at its heart, UNCUT GEMS will transfix the viewer by reflecting something a little different back at you depending on what angle you consider it from.

title: Uncut Gems
review: The Safdies create dazzling, anxiety-inducing mania that spares no moment for viewers to catch their breath... 10/10 recommend.

title: Uncut Gems
review: Possibly one of the most annoying movies I've seen in recent years. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Premature
review: Premature is an extremely vulnerable portrait of a Black teen girl in love... It's also a necessary reality check for those who may have forgotten what real teen love looks like.

title: Premature
review: Sure there are plenty of films about self-discovery and teenage love, but Premature is different- it's a thoughtful work that cuts right to the heart.

title: Premature
review: The visual beauty of Green and Valladao's craft, best demonstrated by a knack for finding soft splashes of color to warm up gelid moments or facilitate passion, positions Premature as a mournful ode to contemporary Black identity.

title: Premature
review: A warm, tender and refreshingly un-Hollywood love story. Zora Howard gives a breakthrough performance

title: Premature
review: In 'Premature', Green weaves the city, the summer atmosphere, and the urgency of young love into a story that will remind you of your first love.

title: Premature
review: Premature begins with electricity. The only kind of electricity you can find on a crowded New York City subway in the summer - and it never goes away thanks to Zora Howard's star-making performance.

title: Premature
review: Howard and Boone have great chemistry, but they're just as strong performers apart as they are together.

title: Premature
review: ... offers a tender and evocative examination of contemporary relationships. Like Ayanna, the film is rough around the edges before you realize it's smarter than it first appears.

title: Premature
review: The way the scenes were shot felt so fresh, so real, and so full of life.

title: Premature
review: This film explores the very real ways that love heals, that it transforms, that it tests and changes us.

title: Premature
review: In the end, Premature was a very good effort but, like the title, it's premature.

title: Premature
review: The old adage "nothing ventured, nothing gained" holds more than true here, both for the movie and the people within it. Yes, love hurts, but without it, what are we?

title: Top End Wedding
review: The tone is not permitted to become too serious and the feelgood ending is never in doubt. We can also be assured that Blair is going to harness all of the Territory's most spectacular features and show them at their most beguiling.

title: Top End Wedding
review: Blair's direction demonstrates significant comedic flair - there are many laugh-out-loud moments - even if the script's scruffy elements cramp his style a little.

title: Top End Wedding
review: "Top End Wedding" strains for broad farce in its tonally yo-yoing first half, before relaxing into a gentler, more poignant tale of familial bonding as the forestalled but inevitable nuptials approach.

title: Top End Wedding
review: The first hour of Top End Wedding can be downright annoying in its simplicity and bad screenwriting.

title: Top End Wedding
review: The traditional Tiwi love song heard in the final scenes and the joyous faces of the locals - mixing trained actors with nonprofessionals - make the destination warmly satisfying, even if it's sometimes a rough ride getting there.

title: Top End Wedding
review: The performances were solid, the picturesque location shots were awesome and the story had enough laugh-out-loud comedy to make it pleasing.

title: Top End Wedding
review: The entire cast, no matter how minor the role, is delightful and delivers in a way the script consistently fails to do.

title: Top End Wedding
review: There's a big heart here, and a fine cast to explore it, with Tapsell a completely charming screen presence, helping the material through potentially sluggish scenes of motivation.

title: Top End Wedding
review: A sweet story about love in all its forms - for marriage, parenthood, heritage, and how far we're willing to go to discover ourselves.

title: Top End Wedding
review: The clash of cultures was an integral part of the story without it being a cheap shortcut for generic laughs

title: Top End Wedding
review: There aren't many surprises, but the amusing bit players, throw-away lines and general "feels" that "Top End Wedding" leaves you with put it over.

title: Top End Wedding
review: Co-writers [Miranda] Tapsell and Joshua Tyler develop a heart-felt and stunning story of true love while remembering the humor that is an integral part of life.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: Mutating into a documentary-style approach, Ozon has a talented cast helping him stabilize the narrative disproportion whenever the film goes up and down in tone.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: Ozon never plays the sentimental card and while the abuse suffered by the men is no doubt horrific, the details of their inner lives remain elusive.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: There's a power to By the Grace of God that could have been less overt -- I'm looking at you, Spotlight poster in the background of one scene -- but it by and large sticks the landing.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: It treats brittle facts with visual delicacy and suggestions that, although we do not see them, are forceful, unforgettable and graceless. [Full review in Spanish]

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The film is not a visual spectacle... but it is the message that possesses the true power and purpose that Ozon evidently wishes to transmit. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The sensitive material of childhood abuse by the church, in a well-researched dramatization, is finely handled by French director-writer François Ozon.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: Beautifully acted and deeply impressive, By the Grace of God is suffused with a simmering anger.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The damage done in writer-director Francois Ozon's incriminating story is as sharply drawn as an assault.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The film is so good that it's hard to tell whether it's a documentary or a feature film. By the Grace of God matters - no matter what.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The actors Melvil Poupaud, Denis Ménochet and Swann Arlaud interpret three survivors with contrasting ethical and religious positions, but also very complementary ones. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: The film's pace is deliberate, made with a documentary style-no histrionics, just raw determination and mounting tension. An important, engrossing work-highly recommended.

title: By the Grace of God (Grâce à Dieu)
review: By the Grace of God winds up being about more than child abuse. It's also about the complex group dynamics that develop when victims seek justice and about the lasting impact of one of the most severe of all imaginable betrayals.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: A syrupy brew thick with twee and an abundance of cringe-inducing moments pulling at heartstrings.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: The movie functions like one of those star-studded Garry Marshall ensemble movies but made terribly sad until the last few minutes, when a tacked-on happy ending arrives in time for the credits.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: [D]ear lord, I've been searching high and low for something nice to say about this mess, and I have come up nearly empty.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: The movie, so determined to celebrate small acts of kindness among those who have least, feels a little too calculated and emphatic - a tearjerker that doesn't quite draw tears.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: I think they've probably hit bottom with this howler, a criss-crossing ensemble piece set in New York and featuring a rogues' gallery of non-characters slowly learning to appreciate the transformative power of (sick bucket please) "forgiveness".

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: Even Home Alone 2 is far more indelible than The Kindness of Strangers.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: The best thing about The Kindness of Strangers is that it is very much a product of our current situation when it comes to the chaotic state of the world we live in. Sometimes we get the downer movies we deserve.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: Lives interconnect in slow-paced drama with brief violence.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: "The Kindness of Strangers" is a mixed bag, though it's led by a wonderful performance by Zoe Kazan. In the end, she does manage to drag this film across the finish line.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: This isn't on a par with Scherfig's best films, but the milieu and situations are immersive and the characters just colorful enough to hold our interest.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: The cast is stellar-Stella!-but everyone checks out long before it's all over.

title: The Kindness of Strangers
review: The inevitable indifference with which this Christmas turkey will be received should be a blessing to everyone involved.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: Zengel is a balled-up fist of energy in the title role, getting across the sweetness that can convince those who take pity on Benni that "she's making progress," but unleashing hell in a flash to remind them she isn't.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: System Crasher is too intense for too long, which may tax viewers' patience. But it's difficult to shake, thanks to Zengel's utterly, admirably fearless contribution to a mindful portrait of trauma and mental illness.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: A magnetic lead perfomance from the young lead but the film takes the easy way out by avoiding any sort of answers.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: A story of heartbreak bandaged up by rebellion, System Crasher will wrench your heart out of your chest and stomp all over it. As you can imagine, it's a painful experience, but one that offers just as many rewards as it does tears.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: Two tenacious lead performances power this uniquely frank yet compassionate examination of angry childhood.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: System Crasher is a careful and complex look at a young girl in desperate need of something that the adults in her life are unable to give her.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: Systemsprenger's nuances elevate the film beyond mere misery porn and into something truly cathartic.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: While the plot lacks a conventional narrative resolution, which would be inappropriate to such a story, the conclusion attempts to bring some levity to Benni's rebellions and her carers' struggles.

title: System Crasher (Systemsprenger)
review: [An] admirable distillation of a tough subject...

title: Goldie
review: Goldie is a bold expression of creativity both in front of and behind the scenes; supporting a film like this is paramount to showing the industry that art films matter.

title: Goldie
review: Goldie's energy is matched by Shawn Peter's kinetic cinematography, which is paired with animation by Smith & Lee, a colorful and undulating aesthetic reminiscent of Klasky-Csupo.

title: Goldie
review: Goldie shows its own brand of stylistic confidence, although it's also clear that the movie doesn't exactly know what it wants to do.

title: Goldie
review: Spirited main character shines in bleak, mature drama.

title: Goldie
review: There's a unique vision at play, from the very first frame of the film, and I wanted to see it to its end.

title: Goldie
review: Woods makes our heroine someone we warm to -- if not right away -- and more importantly, someone we won't forget.

title: Goldie
review: A lively, kinetic film that dances between the natural and the fanciful, centered on a dynamo of a cinematic character played by the first-time actress.

title: Goldie
review: De Jong forces us to face how few real opportunities are given to girls like Goldie, and to understand why someone would be willing to risk it all even to snatch a mere wisp of a dream.

title: Goldie
review: This film is filled with bursts of color. The high energy visuals counterbalance the tragic malaise of Goldie's life perfectly.

title: Goldie
review: De Jong's portrait of an irrepressible New York teenager is as spirited as the central character and should find a welcome in global festivals and territories with an audience for gritty, big-hearted American independent cinema.

title: Tread
review: It all makes for an intriguing setup as we analyze each character and their personal versions of the truth.

title: Tread
review: With a mournful compassion for everyone concerned, Solet delicately probes the fault lines ripped wide open that day by Marv and his bulldozer - whether those faults were there before, or his actions dug them.

title: Tread
review: Businesses destroyed, lives shaken to their core, the cars of bystanders crushed, cops helpless to stop it - it's awful and tragic, sure. But it's something to see, man.

title: Tread
review: An alarming warning sign, "Tread" is a tale of men who work with their calloused, grease infused hands, and despite vast differences, it's the work, the hard, dangerous, painful work that unites them.

title: Tread
review: The blend of archival footage, commentary from the participants and re-enacted dramatization builds with the taut grit of a hardboiled thriller.

title: Tread
review: Paul Solet's Tread takes a little while to grab the audience; however, once the stakes are fully understood, it becomes quite intense.

title: Tread
review: Tread is a compelling and slick documentary about this little known event... the film overall was a bit too polished with some fancy drone shots and slow motion action sequences that felt unnecessary.

title: Impossible Monsters
review: Ultimately Impossible Monsters is a perfectly adequate film with good production values and quite a few engaging twists and turns.

title: Impossible Monsters
review: Stylish and atmospheric, but undercooked and underwhelming.

title: Impossible Monsters
review: The mysterious, suggestive atmosphere primes viewers for an unexpected fantastical element.

title: Impossible Monsters
review: An interesting idea for this thriller-horror is frustrated by poor performances and an unintelligent script.

title: Swallow
review: Writer-director Carlo Mirabella-Davis has made a feminist film that lodges deep in your throat, taking up residence in your chest as you struggle to breathe.

title: Swallow
review: Neither the payoff nor the psychology behind her actions makes "Swallow" an illuminating enough addition to the woman-on-the-verge-of-a-nervous-breakdown genre.

title: Swallow
review: There are really two contending films inside Swallow that, if given the opportunity and the space to do so, could have been fascinating as separate entities.

title: Swallow
review: It's worth seeing for Mirabella-Davis' strong compositions and use of color, along with Bennett's great work.

title: Swallow
review: Carlo Mirabella-Davis' feature debut would be worth recommending if it was simply an impeccably shot meditation on upper-class ennui of the Feminine Mystique variety. That being said, it's much more than that.

title: Swallow
review: By the end, characters who initially seemed so simple have taken on startlingly different personas, revealing the true face of an oppressive system in the process - one in which men make the rules, and can institutionalize those who don't conform.

title: Swallow
review: [Bennett's] incredibly skilled, impressively controlled and subtly powerful performance papers over some of the cracks here, while the styling and candy-bright color pops ensure Swallow goes down smoothly, even in its tougher moments.

title: Swallow
review: [T]he disgust and uneasiness ... overshadow our ability to sympathize with the character...

title: Swallow
review: Despite the bizarre premise, Swallow is one of the most intriguing watches of 2020. It's worth a look. It may be an acquired tasted for some, but it will be a treat for others.

title: Swallow
review: Swallow doesn't always go down smoothly but it does expose how marriage can be a trap, family skeletons continue to rattle and freedom is just another word for nothing left to lose.

title: Swallow
review: [Bennett] perfectly embodies the zombie-like motions that result from existing in this purgatorial limbo [and] the naked suffering underneath.

title: Swallow
review: As the emotional anchor for the film, Bennett gives a revelatory performance in Swallow, one comprised of grace, a stoic sense of determination, and a quiet sense of longing to fit in.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: Chemistry between the leads is key. Schwartz comfortably holds his own against the evergreen Crystal, twinkle still firmly in his eye.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: In Standing Up, Falling Down, this new style of comedy is light on laughs, but big on heart, weaving together a story of hope, redemption, and second chances with a solid cast led by Ben Schwartz and Billy Crystal.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: 'Standing Up, Falling Down' falters by presenting too many awkward scenes that don't seem real. But Billy Crystal fans should enjoy his splendid performance as an alcoholic estranged from his angry son.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: When all is said and done, Standing Up, Falling Down is a heartwarming film about getting a second chance in life.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: This dramedy is at its best when it puts its central, mismatched pair in the same place and allows Schwartz' and Crystal's shared chemistry to percolate.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: Hey, 'Standing Up' is nothing particularly profound, just a nice little keeper. Go out to find it and enjoy.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: ... maintains an agreeable balance of humor and pathos, bolstered by Crystal's affecting portrayal.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: A surprise and delight... I loved seeing Billy Crystal getting the chance to really act again.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: You won't be surprised by anything that happens, but then it isn't that kind of movie; it's the kind of movie you stumble across on Netflix or Crave and wonder how you missed it the first time around.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: Billy Crystal and Ben Schwartz score in touching dramedy about second chances.

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: A film that bravely dares to answer the heretofore unasked question "What would 'Garden State' have been like if the Natalie Portman role had been filled by Billy Crystal?"

title: Standing Up, Falling Down
review: The film's deft and beautifully scripted with terrific performances by each and all.

title: After We Leave
review: I was blown away by how good After We Leave looks, its subtlety and plausibility and confident simplicity.

title: After We Leave
review: Once in a while, a budget indie film comes along that makes us glad this art form is still around. After We Leave is a shining example of indie filmmaking at its finest.

title: After We Leave
review: Although it does get a little bumpy along the way, Aleem Hossain's feature film debut remains a promising genre entry.

title: After We Leave
review: His ultimate dilemma... is deftly handled and moving, ensuring that Hossain's 'one last job' scenario, for all its futurist gizmos (temple phones, paralytic implants, etc), stays down to earth.

title: Black Christmas
review: The choice to go PG-13 on the gore and thrill level for this reboot makes it feel more like a TV movie than a feature film. Still, it was probably the right choice for the intended audience.

title: Black Christmas
review: Despite its desperate efforts to justify the homicides, there's nothing remotely innovative or even goofily satirical about it.

title: Black Christmas
review: At its best, "Black Christmas" is a smart alternative to slasher horror, and Takal provides a needed voice in the current conversation. Her message is clear, but her execution needs some work.

title: Black Christmas
review: It has plenty of ideas, but falls short in delivering the scares.

title: Black Christmas
review: Takal and Wolfe distinguish their film with an in-your-face fury aimed at contemporary campus culture's negligent approach to sexual assault and the ways in which women are forced to deal in its aftermath.

title: Black Christmas
review: Fans of the original ... might not love writer-director Sophia Takal's take, but Black Christmas is a fun film that gets its kicks out of literally smashing the patriarchy.

title: Black Christmas
review: Black Christmas ends up being a lump of coal with its poor screenplay and weak character development, even if it has some fun moments.

title: Black Christmas
review: Wrong-headed is an understatement in this new approach to the material and we are taken for a third act ride that is equal parts baffling and preposterous.

title: Black Christmas
review: We need more feminist genre cinema, but that doesn't mean we have to accept half-baked films like this.

title: Black Christmas
review: I love the mass murder of a bunch of rapist Kavanaughs as much as anyone, believe me, though I'm not sure the catharsis it proffers is anything but temporary--or, worse, merely palliative.

title: Black Christmas
review: A darkly satisfying festive surprise. ...A rallying cry for all of us to be fighters, to stop just accepting that this is how things are, and to take control of our destiny.

title: Black Christmas
review: The #MeToo movement was a primal scream that rose up from the throats of women. Black Christmas is an echo of that initial feeling.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blood on Her Name is a sleek indie thriller with dread that just constantly churns throughout its breezy runtime...smart and heart-wrenching.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: BLOOD ON HER NAME is a New American Gothic treasure that keeps viewers captivated from start to finish with its full circle tale.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Gripping stuff, thanks to compassionate writing and a stunning lead performance.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blood on Her Name is a surprisingly fresh and empathetic look at mayhem in small-town America.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: There's a refreshing simplicity to this gritty thriller, as filmmaker Matthew Pope uses well-worn but effective cinematic language to build suspense and a strong sense of unease.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Pope, Thompson, and lead actress Lind work together to create a visceral portrait of paranoia and anxiety that draws tension from its exploration of cycles of violence.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: It's flawed, but it's a tightly wound, mournful thriller about a young woman in a very bad situation.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Lind is such a skillful actress that the occasional implausibility and moral ambiguity of Leigh's situation becomes compelling and rather suspenseful.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: This Southern gothic neo-noir (that's a mouthful!) is based on a woman who accidentally kills a man while defending herself. Panicked, she decides to cover up the death.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: ...a good yarn is a good yarn, and the mismatch of the film's various elements can't fully derail the good ideas at play here.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blood On Her Name is alive and invested in its characters so much that it allows them to go where they would for reasons that make sense to them.

title: Blood on Her Name
review: Blending elements of crime-thriller and revisionist Western, Blood on Her Name delivers a uniquely exciting experience.

title: Ne Zha
review: In some very important ways, it's competing right up to the level of Pixar or Disney themselves.

title: Ne Zha
review: It is not a major achievement in the genre - other than in the commercial sense - but it is a bold and promising step along the road.

title: Ne Zha
review: Ne Zha has some shaky storytelling to begin with, but by the second half, it escalates into a full-fledged emotional animated blockbuster.

title: Ne Zha
review: Ne Zha tells a fantastical story of Gods, power and finding your place in the world no matter who you are. It possesses buckets of charm, chemistry and comedy that places it amongst the elite animated films from across the globe.

title: Ne Zha
review: There are several eye-popping action sequences, and while the final act feels over- indulgent, Ne Zha is still a praiseworthy effort.

title: Ne Zha
review: ...a glorious panorama unto itself.

title: Ne Zha
review: It's very hard to make sense of... [During] a lot of it, you just feel like you're wandering some trackless wilderness.

title: Ne Zha
review: Lots of fantasy violence in animation based on Chinese myth.

title: Ne Zha
review: Strange and funny enough to recommend on its own.

title: Ne Zha
review: Conventionally animated but paced with kinetic glee, Ne Zha crams in a plethora of contemporary and pop culture references, and in those moments it's at its least fun and most obvious.

title: Ne Zha
review: The film remains whimsical and entertaining for adults and children alike, and its treatment of a Chinese folk deity is surprisingly accessible for audiences unfamiliar with Chinese mythology.

title: Bombshell
review: The entertainingly potent Fox News docu-satire, Bombshell, is jammed with incident - largely based on events at the network during the 2015 election cycle - but the film's most unsettling nugget is one that's presented in the first five minutes.

title: Bombshell
review: It's this element of recoil from total sympathy with these harassed women that makes the film intriguing though.

title: Bombshell
review: [A] timely satirical takedown that finds black humour and absurdist comedy in the subject of workplace sexual harassment while never losing sight of its devastating repercussions.

title: Bombshell
review: [Director Jay Roach] and Randolph are rightly fascinated by the social climate and geography of the Fox offices -- the factions, hierarchies, protocols and rivalries that define the place.

title: Bombshell
review: Disingenuous trash.

title: Bombshell
review: Charlize Theron, Nicole Kidman, John Lithgow at the top of their game in a solid recap of sexual harassment at Fox News.

title: Bombshell
review: A confused depiction of fact. Great makeup and performances but a disastrous script make this one a disappointing film. [Full review in Spanish].

title: Bombshell
review: While it touches on the toxic masculinity and systematic sexism that permeates Fox News, it does little to contextualize the industry that allowed this behavior to thrive.

title: Bombshell
review: The film wields its arms to signal that its time to step aside and let women take their spots as leads in their own stories. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Bombshell
review: The performances in the film are spot-on, especially Theron as Kelly.

title: Bombshell
review: Theron and Robbie do a lot with characters that, at least on paper, don't appear to be quite three-dimensional. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Bombshell
review: The obsession with real dates... the insistence on resemblance and makeup prostheses, the need for a frantic narrative rhythm... [are] obstacles that endanger the project's original nobility. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Color Out of Space
review: There are messages about the environment, the media and there are lots of laughs, it is quite genre-defying in ways.

title: Color Out of Space
review: The gruesome events and Cage's varied performance (opposite Joely Richardson as his wife) make steady entertainment for fans of weird horror. Given its potential, though, Richard Stanley's film is a touch disappointing.

title: Color Out of Space
review: ... this eldritch tale seems ready-made for a Nic Cage vehicle... a beautiful picture of a descent into madness, an acceptance of inevitability, and a family truly brought together as none have before.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Create a hazy sense of itchy otherworldliness cohabiting with the quotidian space of a rundown farm.

title: Color Out of Space
review: a trippy rainbow of the gory and the grotesque

title: Color Out of Space
review: This sci-fi horror has a superb everyday tone that director-cowriter Richard Stanley cleverly warps into bonkers body snatchers nastiness. Subtle effects and freak-out set-pieces put the audience increasingly on edge.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Befitting the title, Stanley makes a magical use of colour, deep pinks and blues and greens visually stunning and eventually terrifying, before all this saturation and brightness gives way to a climactic explosion of grey.

title: Color Out of Space
review: For Cage completists only.

title: Color Out of Space
review: [A]s the toxic alien presence exerts its grip on the surrounding area, both star and film go properly nuts, with Cage subdued one minute and howling at the moon the next and Stanley's visuals toggling between psychotropic weirdness and outright gore.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Aside from a couple of missteps, the film is endlessly imaginative and, as suits its title, showcases a vibrant visual palette.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Stanley's film is a weird, nasty little treat- climate change horror filled with spacey neon pleasures and proper existential terror.

title: Color Out of Space
review: Color Out of Space is gloriously old school, stomach-churning, rib-tickling and strangely poignant, with warnings about big business and dirty water thrown in amid the gunge.

title: Dark Waters
review: The groundswell of dogged determination propelling this environmental thriller is so powerful that it deals effortlessly with the knotty tangle of facts packed into its plot. Much of this is down to the film's star and initiator, Mark Ruffalo.

title: Dark Waters
review: The subject deserved better.

title: Dark Waters
review: In Dark Waters, [Todd Haynes] bathes his audience in pure terror like very few other directors could.

title: Dark Waters
review: True to its title, this is a murky pool of a movie, and Mark Ruffalo is the man on the bank, poking its surface with a stick.

title: Dark Waters
review: A movie that works marvellously well within its own generic terms...

title: Dark Waters
review: The Bilotts make compelling viewing, straight arrows losing the scales from their eyes.

title: Dark Waters
review: There is, admittedly, a dark fascination in seeing how flagrantly giant companies mess with people's lives. As an expose about corporate malfeasance, Dark Waters is especially topical and timely given the findings of the recent banking inquiry.

title: Dark Waters
review: It's effective rather than exciting and the narrative is more than strong enough to grip the attention even if it is overly long.

title: Dark Waters
review: A fine issues-based affair worthy of comparison to the likes of Silkwood, The Insider and Erin Brockovich.

title: Dark Waters
review: While worthy and important, Dark Waters is a functional, by-numbers legal drama that is illuminating without setting your world alight.

title: Dark Waters
review: They say nothing sticks to Teflon, and in Todd Haynes' corporate conspiracy drama Dark Waters, you'll realise that not much sticks to evil corporations either.

title: Dark Waters
review: That said, the inherent exasperation seems to accurately represent the endless setbacks, obfuscations, and heartaches inherent in fighting for corporate environmental justice.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Shin infuses an intoxicating blend of grime, crime, and style into Disappearance at Clifton Hill, all of which make it a twisted treat to enjoy.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Disappearance at Clifton Hill suffers from an incoherent and uninspired script even if it boasts great performances and stellar technical achievements.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: As an ambiguous look at the nature of truth and deception, Clifton Hill has an unsettling low-key potency, which is why the final third - when the plotting gets strained and Shin wraps things up with a "gotcha" ending - is so disappointing.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: The septuagenarian filmmaker does great supporting work in a film that's otherwise long on atmosphere but short on specifics...

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Earning more points for style than substance, this atmospheric Canadian noir lacks enough tension to sufficiently pay off its titular mystery.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: What sets "Disappearance at Clifton Hill" apart is how quietly menacing it all feels.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Anchored by a solid performance from Middleton, lush production, and solid writing, we have a delicious mystery that confounds as much as it beguiles.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: [Writer-director Albert] Shin's haunting Niagara Noir delivers the chills and a dripping wet David Cronenberg as a grinning Botticelli Venus.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Worth watching for Middleton's compelling central performance, the intricate noirish plot and the well-designed and shot retro locations.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Albert Shin's Disappearance at Clifton Hill is a neo-noir told mainly in nostalgic colors, smoke and mirrors.

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Shin and co-screenwriter James Schultz have given us a most unique detective...

title: Disappearance at Clifton Hill
review: Does so many things right that it's unfortunate that, in the end, it proves a disappointment.

title: The Dark Red
review: Director-cowriter Dan Bush is an assured filmmaker who carefully builds the story using darkly dramatic flashbacks before flipping everything on its head.

title: The Dark Red
review: Twisty psychological thriller.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red isn't afraid to get a little bloody, and it's all the more entertaining for it.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red is an interesting way of exploring the hysterical mother trope. Helped massively by a great lead performance, The Dark Red may just have birthed the next screen Sarah Connor.

title: The Dark Red
review: Dan Bush's The Dark Red is a tale of maternity and madness, vampiric predation and class exploitation.

title: The Dark Red
review: The Dark Red is a smart little film with a more sophisticated understanding of its subject matter and more to say than past stories of this sort might lead you to expect.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: [A] brash, crass, often mind-numbing ride.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: A satire of overamped gamer culture that is itself too overamped to be much fun...

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Writer-director Jason Lei Howden's humor might have been tolerable if his film was at least reasonably imaginative.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Anyone with an attention span above ADD levels... is likely to find this undeniably slick, energetic contraption plays somewhere between grating and numbing.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: It's somehow exhausting but not exhilarating, a non-stop chase scene that would be a good deal more fun if not getting caught seemed even like a one-in-a-million prospect.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: The film is a perfect example of a promising concept being ruined by a visually and audibly obnoxious execution. Its nonstop video game references make Guns Akimbo feel like a film that is too aware for its own good.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Restricted to 95 minutes, the film doesn't try to do more than the bizarre premise promises, which is an off-the-wall shoot 'em up featuring a reluctant and ill-qualified hero.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Guns Akimbo is a force to be reckoned with and is a film that can confidently stand alongside early Peter Jackson or Mark L. Lester. Run to see this wild, insane ride.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Writer-director Jason Lei Howden plays even the most grotesquely over-the-top nastiness for laughs, celebrating each moment of death or dismemberment. While some viewers may be appalled by this, fans of trashy carnage will love it.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Frenetic might be an understatement here. Adrenaline rush is delivered as you are watching.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Guns Akimbo is finally a well-directed film, edited with clarity and a keen sense of pacing by the team of Luke Haigh and Zaz Montana.

title: Guns Akimbo
review: Has this juvenile, punk rock vibe that mostly works really well-even if it is weirdly juxtaposed with some unnecessary serious comments about how violence actually is "in real life".

title: The Climbers
review: While emphasizing spectacle over substance, this true-life adventure about Chinese mountaineers trying to climb Mount Everest is only sporadically stirring.

title: The Climbers
review: The Climbers had the potential to be a gripping drama-thriller and project China's soft power while doing so, but instead the overt focus on fighting for national pride makes the film a flop.

title: The Climbers
review: This account of the Chinese Mount Everest expeditions in 1960 and 1975 is a nationalistic spectacle that, curiously, often also allows personal sentiment to get in the way of the greater good.

title: Richard Jewell
review: This is, frankly, a political film and it's no secret that Eastwood is not exactly on the left, but, ever the pragmatist, he leaves room for multiple readings.

title: Richard Jewell
review: It's not Eastwood's finest hour.

title: Richard Jewell
review: In many ways, it is a very good story, efficiently told - and that's down to the excellent and very plausible performance from Paul Walter Hauser.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Richard Jewell is pointed and compelling - so much so that it needn't underline its themes as thickly as it does.

title: Richard Jewell
review: In Clint Eastwood's hands, Richard Jewell becomes a martyr to the director's career-long cause: heroism when it exists in direct opposition to authority.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Nothing is accidental in a Clint Eastwood film - such is the shame of Richard Jewell.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Where it falters - and badly - is in its portrayal of real-life reporter Kathy Scruggs. It leaves a bitter taste and mars the whole package, undermining its own good work elsewhere.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Paul Walter Hauser's powerhouse performance firms this tale of an American hero robbed of his glory as one of Clint Eastwood's most exceptional efforts from the last decade.

title: Richard Jewell
review: The story Eastwood is telling here is indeed a compelling one, a real-life drama recounting the abuse of power by the two most powerful institutions in America, the government and the press.

title: Richard Jewell
review: Richard Jewell does well to tell a little-known story and is probably the best dramatisation of these events that there can be.

title: Richard Jewell
review: It's a sloppily made, slapdash affair that coasts entirely on a handful of excellent performances and the goodwill afforded to it by its intended audience.

title: Richard Jewell
review: The indefatigable Eastwood's latest turn in the director's chair tackles the real life story of 1990s security guard Richard Jewell in a biopic with strong playing alongside a few controversial decisions and queasy touches.

title: Greenlight
review: At 83 minutes, Greenlight is slower in parts than a thriller/horror should be and should never give you time to think, but it's a taut ride with some crazy fun shots.

title: Greenlight
review: A horror tale a little too good to be a "film festival only" movie, a little too promising to appreciate on its own pedestrian terms.

title: Greenlight
review: An interesting spin on the Hollywood machine, Greenlight is an enjoyable exploration of the lengths some people will go to to achieve their dreams.

title: Greenlight
review: While it's not perfect and the pacing is a bit muddled, Greenlight really nails the relationship between the young upstart director and the world-weary producer.

title: Greenlight
review: Greenlight is a tight thriller with some thrilling twists and you should catch it before it blows up big.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing He Wanted seems so taken with its own intricacy that it manages only to trip itself up.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: What makes The Last Thing He Wanted ultimately so frustrating (while also elevating it a few notches above its awfulness as a thriller) is the fact that there are things it does quite well.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: How does a director as stellar as Dee Rees go so thunderously wrong adapting a 1996 novel by the great Joan Didion, with a cast headed by Anne Hathaway, Ben Affleck, and Willem Dafoe? Here's Exhibit A and the last thing any of us wanted.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: I found the whole narrative confusing. Even if you can parse it out, it doesn't add up to a whole lot.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: There's some overreach and muddle here - you wouldn't want a pop quiz on the plot - but "Last Thing" remains an intriguing, visually diverting piece, well shot by Bobby Bukowski.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The big problem with the movie isn't the muddle, but the strain.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: A convoluted and incoherent political thriller meant to get lost in Netflix's vast catalogue. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: Not even Anne Hathaway can save this one.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: [Anne Hathaway] never becomes an interesting character... Willem Dafoe can't save the disaster either. [Full review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing has the pizzazz and the cinematic bravado necessary for a taut political thriller, but the film falls flat from the outset.

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: Nothing works properly and with genuine conviction in The Last Thing He Wanted. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: The Last Thing He Wanted
review: The Last Thing He Wanted is a political thriller so incoherent, disjointed, convoluted, and boring that its very existence proves to be perplexing.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Its pure beating heart and humanistic undertones make it somewhat of a standout.

title: All the Bright Places
review: A refreshingly sober spin on YA romance.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Elle Fanning and Justice Smith are gorgeous together and have lovely chemistry.

title: All the Bright Places
review: There's messaging inserted near the start of the end credits for those who might be affected by the themes raised. But it doesn't negate what comes before it: a film that lingers briefly in the deep end but remains disappointingly shallow.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Though it's not without humor, "All the Bright Places" takes teens' emotions seriously and will move romantics of any age - in possibly unexpected ways.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Smith and Fanning bring thoughtful performances to this delicate tale.

title: All the Bright Places
review: While [All the Bright Places] remains sensitive towards its heavy themes of mental-illness and suicide, it also ends up being a little problematic in it's road to closure.

title: All the Bright Places
review: 'All the Bright Places' impressed me with its honesty, compassion, and sensitive performances by Elle Fanning and Justice Smith, who project amazing chemistry together on screen.

title: All the Bright Places
review: In a world full of inexplicable book-to-film adaptations, All the Bright Places is a diamond in the rough.

title: All the Bright Places
review: It also shows people of all ages that this too shall pass, that humans are resilient but also fragile, and life will continuously surprise you. I think that All The Bright Places is a beautiful film. You will probably cry, but it will be worth it.

title: All the Bright Places
review: Charming, sweet, and often deeply gripping and emotional, All the Bright Places is a mesmerizing coming-of-age story told with immense skill.

title: All the Bright Places
review: [T]here is an undeniable warmth and tenderness to Fanning and Smith's performances that makes this a worthy, if not particularly memorable, addition to a thriving sub-genre.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: There were some very high highs and some very low lows...the 49-minute special is a pretty wild ride. Like, yes, I was chuckling almost the whole time, but there were low points, friends...

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: Davidson runs thin on material, especially when you cut out extended, poorly paced anecdotes about fellow celebrities.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: The cycle begins anew. Alive From New York is designed to trigger a modest but manageable backlash. Whatever happens from here-good, bad, or ugly-you can bet Davidson will at least get some material out of it.

title: Pete Davidson: Alive From New York
review: This performance is so raw, director Jason Orley leaves in not just the parts Davidson says he'd cut from the special, but also the aside the comic makes to him from onstage about a joke he wants left in, too.
